code: library(ClinicoPath) library(survival) library(dplyr)

title: jSurvival 01: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Pathologists
code:
# Load molecular pathology survival data data(ihc_molecular_comprehensive)  # Survival data structure cat("Survival dataset dimensions:", nrow(ihc_molecular_comprehensive), "×", ncol(ihc_molecular_comprehensive), "
")  # Key survival variables survival_vars <- c("Overall_Survival_Months", "Death_Event", "PFS_Months", "Progression_Event") cat("Survival variables:", paste(survival_vars, collapse = ", "), "
")  # Molecular biomarkers for stratification biomarker_vars <- c("EGFR_Mutation", "MSI_Status", "HER2_IHC", "PD_L1_TPS") cat("Biomarker variables:", paste(biomarker_vars, collapse = ", "), "
")  # Basic survival summary survival_summary <- ihc_molecular_comprehensive %>%   summarise(     n = n(),     median_os = median(Overall_Survival_Months),     death_rate = round(mean(Death_Event) * 100, 1),     median_pfs = median(PFS_Months),     progression_rate = round(mean(Progression_Event) * 100, 1)   )  cat("
Survival Summary:
") cat("Patients:", survival_summary$n, "
") cat("Median OS:", survival_summary$median_os, "months
") cat("Death rate:", survival_summary$death_rate, "%
") cat("Median PFS:", survival_summary$median_pfs, "months
") cat("Progression rate:", survival_summary$progression_rate, "%
")

title: jSurvival 01: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Pathologists
text: Foundation survival analysis time--event data.
code:
# Kaplan-Meier Analysis Example # In jamovi: jsurvival > Survival Analysis  cat("Kaplan-Meier Survival Analysis
") cat("==============================

")  if(requireNamespace("survival", quietly = TRUE)) {   library(survival)      # Create survival object   surv_obj <- Surv(ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Overall_Survival_Months,                    ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Death_Event)      # Overall survival curve   km_overall <- survfit(surv_obj ~ 1, data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)      cat("Overall Survival Analysis:
")   print(summary(km_overall, times = c(12, 24, 36, 60))$table)      # Survival by EGFR mutation status   km_egfr <- survfit(surv_obj ~ EGFR_Mutation, data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)      cat("
Survival by EGFR Status:
")   egfr_summary <- summary(km_egfr)$table   print(egfr_summary)      # Log-rank test   logrank_egfr <- survdiff(surv_obj ~ EGFR_Mutation, data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)   p_value <- 1 - pchisq(logrank_egfr$chisq, 1)      cat("
Log-rank test p-value:", round(p_value, 4), "
")      if(p_value < 0.05) {     cat("Conclusion: Significant difference in survival by EGFR status
")   } else {     cat("Conclusion: No significant difference in survival by EGFR status
")   } }

title: jSurvival 01: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Pathologists
text: Multivariable analysis accounting multiple prognostic factors.
code:
# Cox Regression Analysis Example # In jamovi: jsurvival > Cox Diagnostics  cat("
Cox Proportional Hazards Regression
") cat("===================================

")  if(requireNamespace("survival", quietly = TRUE)) {   # Multivariable Cox model   cox_model <- coxph(Surv(Overall_Survival_Months, Death_Event) ~                       EGFR_Mutation + MSI_Status + Age + Grade + Tumor_Mutational_Burden,                      data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)      cat("Cox Regression Results:
")   cox_summary <- summary(cox_model)   print(cox_summary$coefficients[, c("coef", "exp(coef)", "Pr(>|z|)")])      # Model performance   cat("
Model Performance:
")   cat("Concordance:", round(cox_summary$concordance[1], 3), "
")   cat("R-squared:", round(cox_summary$rsq[1], 3), "
")   cat("Likelihood ratio test p-value:", round(cox_summary$logtest[3], 4), "
")      # Hazard ratios with confidence intervals   cat("
Hazard Ratios (95% CI):
")   hr_ci <- exp(confint(cox_model))   hr_estimates <- exp(cox_model$coefficients)      for(i in 1:length(hr_estimates)) {     var_name <- names(hr_estimates)[i]     hr <- round(hr_estimates[i], 2)     ci_lower <- round(hr_ci[i, 1], 2)     ci_upper <- round(hr_ci[i, 2], 2)     p_val <- round(cox_summary$coefficients[i, "Pr(>|z|)"], 3)          cat(paste0(var_name, ": HR = ", hr, " (", ci_lower, "-", ci_upper, "), p = ", p_val, "
"))   } }

title: jSurvival 01: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Pathologists
text: Handle situations multiple types events can occur.
code:
# Competing Risks Analysis Example # In jamovi: jsurvival > Competing Survival  cat("
Competing Risks Analysis
") cat("=======================

")  # Create competing events data # Death from disease vs death from other causes competing_data <- ihc_molecular_comprehensive %>%   mutate(     # Simulate competing events     death_cause = case_when(       Death_Event == 0 ~ "Alive",       Death_Event == 1 & Grade == 3 ~ "Disease",       Death_Event == 1 & Age > 75 ~ "Other",       Death_Event == 1 ~ sample(c("Disease", "Other"), 1, prob = c(0.7, 0.3)),       TRUE ~ "Alive"     ),          # Competing event indicator     event_type = case_when(       death_cause == "Disease" ~ 1,       death_cause == "Other" ~ 2,       TRUE ~ 0     )   )  # Competing risks summary competing_summary <- competing_data %>%   group_by(death_cause) %>%   summarise(     n = n(),     percentage = round(n() / nrow(competing_data) * 100, 1),     median_time = median(Overall_Survival_Months),     .groups = 'drop'   )  cat("Competing Events Summary:
") print(competing_summary)  # Event rates by biomarker status biomarker_events <- competing_data %>%   group_by(EGFR_Mutation, death_cause) %>%   summarise(n = n(), .groups = 'drop') %>%   group_by(EGFR_Mutation) %>%   mutate(percentage = round(n / sum(n) * 100, 1))  cat("
Event Rates by EGFR Status:
") print(biomarker_events)  # Clinical interpretation disease_death_rate <- mean(competing_data$death_cause == "Disease") * 100 cat("
Clinical Interpretation:
") cat("Disease-specific death rate:", round(disease_death_rate, 1), "%
")  if(disease_death_rate > 50) {   cat("Conclusion: Disease is the predominant cause of death
") } else {   cat("Conclusion: Competing causes of death are significant
") }

title: jSurvival 01: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Pathologists
text: Evaluate prognostic impact molecular biomarkers.
code:
cat("Molecular Biomarker Survival Analysis
") cat("====================================

")  # Multiple biomarker analysis biomarkers <- c("EGFR_Mutation", "MSI_Status", "HER2_IHC")  for(biomarker in biomarkers) {   cat(paste0("Survival Analysis for ", biomarker, ":
"))   cat(paste0(rep("-", nchar(biomarker) + 25), collapse = ""), "
")      # Create survival object   surv_obj <- Surv(ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Overall_Survival_Months,                    ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Death_Event)      # Survival by biomarker   formula_str <- paste("surv_obj ~", biomarker)   km_biomarker <- survfit(as.formula(formula_str), data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)      # Summary statistics   biomarker_summary <- summary(km_biomarker)$table   print(biomarker_summary)      # Log-rank test   logrank_test <- survdiff(as.formula(formula_str), data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)   p_value <- 1 - pchisq(logrank_test$chisq, length(unique(ihc_molecular_comprehensive[[biomarker]])) - 1)      cat("Log-rank test p-value:", round(p_value, 4), "
")      if(p_value < 0.05) {     cat("Result: Significant prognostic biomarker
")   } else {     cat("Result: Not a significant prognostic biomarker
")   }   cat("
") }

title: jSurvival 01: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Pathologists
text: Evaluate continuous biomarkers like PD-L1 expression tumor mutational burden.
code:
cat("Continuous Biomarker Analysis
") cat("=============================

")  # PD-L1 TPS analysis pdl1_quartiles <- quantile(ihc_molecular_comprehensive$PD_L1_TPS,                            probs = c(0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1.0))  ihc_with_quartiles <- ihc_molecular_comprehensive %>%   mutate(     PD_L1_Quartile = cut(PD_L1_TPS,                          breaks = pdl1_quartiles,                         labels = c("Q1 (Low)", "Q2", "Q3", "Q4 (High)"),                         include.lowest = TRUE),          PD_L1_Clinical = case_when(       PD_L1_TPS < 1 ~ "Negative (<1%)",       PD_L1_TPS < 50 ~ "Low Positive (1-49%)",       TRUE ~ "High Positive (≥50%)"     )   )  cat("PD-L1 TPS Distribution:
") pdl1_dist <- table(ihc_with_quartiles$PD_L1_Clinical) print(pdl1_dist)  # Survival by PD-L1 clinical categories if(requireNamespace("survival", quietly = TRUE)) {   surv_obj <- Surv(ihc_with_quartiles$Overall_Survival_Months,                    ihc_with_quartiles$Death_Event)      km_pdl1 <- survfit(surv_obj ~ PD_L1_Clinical, data = ihc_with_quartiles)      cat("
Survival by PD-L1 Expression Level:
")   pdl1_summary <- summary(km_pdl1)$table   print(pdl1_summary)      # Test for trend   logrank_pdl1 <- survdiff(surv_obj ~ PD_L1_Clinical, data = ihc_with_quartiles)   p_value_pdl1 <- 1 - pchisq(logrank_pdl1$chisq, 2)      cat("Log-rank test p-value:", round(p_value_pdl1, 4), "
")      # Tumor mutational burden analysis   tmb_median <- median(ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Tumor_Mutational_Burden)   tmb_high <- ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Tumor_Mutational_Burden >= tmb_median      cat("
Tumor Mutational Burden Analysis:
")   cat("Median TMB:", tmb_median, "mutations/Mb
")   cat("TMB-High cases:", sum(tmb_high), "(", round(mean(tmb_high) * 100, 1), "%)
")      # TMB survival analysis   km_tmb <- survfit(surv_obj ~ tmb_high, data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)   tmb_summary <- summary(km_tmb)$table      cat("Survival by TMB Status:
")   print(tmb_summary) }

title: jSurvival 01: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Pathologists
text: Develop comprehensive prognostic models incorporating multiple biomarkers.
code:
cat("Multivariable Prognostic Model Development
") cat("=========================================

")  if(requireNamespace("survival", quietly = TRUE)) {   # Comprehensive prognostic model   prog_model <- coxph(Surv(Overall_Survival_Months, Death_Event) ~                        Age + Grade +                        EGFR_Mutation + MSI_Status +                        PD_L1_TPS + Tumor_Mutational_Burden,                       data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)      # Model summary   prog_summary <- summary(prog_model)      cat("Comprehensive Prognostic Model:
")   print(prog_summary$coefficients[, c("coef", "exp(coef)", "Pr(>|z|)")])      # Model performance metrics   cat("
Model Performance:
")   cat("Concordance index:", round(prog_summary$concordance[1], 3), "
")   cat("Standard error:", round(prog_summary$concordance[2], 3), "
")      # Risk score calculation   risk_scores <- predict(prog_model, type = "risk")   risk_tertiles <- cut(risk_scores,                        breaks = quantile(risk_scores, probs = c(0, 1/3, 2/3, 1)),                       labels = c("Low Risk", "Intermediate Risk", "High Risk"),                       include.lowest = TRUE)      # Risk group validation   risk_validation <- ihc_molecular_comprehensive %>%     mutate(Risk_Group = risk_tertiles) %>%     group_by(Risk_Group) %>%     summarise(       n = n(),       events = sum(Death_Event),       event_rate = round(mean(Death_Event) * 100, 1),       median_survival = median(Overall_Survival_Months),       .groups = 'drop'     )      cat("
Risk Group Validation:
")   print(risk_validation)      # Test risk stratification   surv_risk <- Surv(ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Overall_Survival_Months,                     ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Death_Event)      km_risk <- survfit(surv_risk ~ risk_tertiles)   logrank_risk <- survdiff(surv_risk ~ risk_tertiles)   p_value_risk <- 1 - pchisq(logrank_risk$chisq, 2)      cat("Risk stratification p-value:", round(p_value_risk, 4), "
")      if(p_value_risk < 0.001) {     cat("Conclusion: Excellent risk stratification achieved
")   } else if(p_value_risk < 0.05) {     cat("Conclusion: Significant risk stratification achieved
")   } else {     cat("Conclusion: Risk stratification needs improvement
")   } }

text: Person-time analysis fundamental concept epidemiology survival analysis accounts varying observation periods study participants. jsurvival module ClinicoPath provides comprehensive person-time calculations incidence rate analysis across survival analysis functions.

title: Person-Time Analysis in jsurvival Module
text: Person-time represents total observation time contributed participants study risk event interest. Unlike simple participant counts, person-time captures number subjects observation duration, providing accurate denominators rate calculations.

title: Person-Time Analysis in jsurvival Module
text: Total Person-Time: Overall observation time Overall Incidence Rate: Events per 100 person-time units Time-Specific Rates: Rates different follow-periods Group Comparisons: Rate differences groups Confidence Intervals: Precision rate estimates

title: Person-Time Analysis in jsurvival Module
text: Scenario: Comparing survival two treatment groups Analysis Setup: - Module: Survival Analysis - Variables: treatment_group, survival_months, death_status - Enable: Person-time metrics Expected Results: - Person-time treatment group - Group-specific incidence rates - Rate ratios treatments - Time-stratified analysis Interpretation:
code: Standard Treatment: 45 deaths in 2,400 person-months (1.88 per 100 person-months) New Treatment: 32 deaths in 2,200 person-months (1.45 per 100 person-months) Rate Ratio: 0.77 (23% reduction in death rate)

title: Person-Time Analysis in jsurvival Module
text: Scenario: Disease incidence exposed vs. unexposed populations Analysis Setup: - Module: Survival Analysis - Variables: exposure_status, followup_years, disease_onset - Enable: Person-time metrics Expected Results: - Exposure-specific person-time - Incidence rates exposure - Time trends incidence - Rate differences ratios Interpretation:
code: Exposed Group: 15 cases in 850 person-years (1.76 per 100 person-years) Unexposed Group: 8 cases in 920 person-years (0.87 per 100 person-years) Rate Difference: 0.89 per 100 person-years Relative Risk: 2.03

title: Person-Time Analysis in jsurvival Module
text: Scenario: Adverse event rates drug therapy Analysis Setup: - Module: Single Arm Survival - Variables: treatment_duration, adverse_event - Enable: Person-time metrics time stratification Expected Results: - Overall adverse event rate - Time-stratified rates (early vs. late) - Confidence intervals safety assessment Interpretation:
code: Overall Rate: 12 events in 1,500 person-months (0.80 per 100 person-months) 0-6 months: 8 events in 600 person-months (1.33 per 100 person-months) 6+ months: 4 events in 900 person-months (0.44 per 100 person-months) Conclusion: Higher event rate in early treatment period

title: Person-Time Analysis in jsurvival Module
text: Person-time analysis can stratified time intervals detect: - Changing hazards time - Early vs. late event patterns - Treatment effect modifications - Time-dependent risk factors Setup: Specify intervals “Time Interval Stratification” option
code: Example: "6, 12, 24" creates intervals: 0-6, 6-12, 12-24, 24+ months

title: Person-Time Analysis in jsurvival Module
text: Choose appropriate multipliers based event frequency: - Rate per 100 person-time: Common moderate event rates - Rate per 1000 person-time: Useful rare events - Rate per 10,000 person-time: rare events

title: Person-Time Analysis in jsurvival Module
text: Person-time rates use Poisson exact confidence intervals: - Exact method: Based Poisson distribution event counts - Conservative approach: Provides accurate coverage - Asymmetric intervals: Reflects nature count data

title: Person-Time Analysis in jsurvival Module
text: Person-time analysis complements traditional survival methods: - Kaplan-Meier curves: Show survival probability time - Cox regression: Models hazard rates (instantaneous person-time rates) - Log-rank tests: Compare survival distributions - Person-time rates: Provide absolute risk measures

title: Person-Time Analysis in jsurvival Module
text: person-time analysis: Check time variables: Ensure positive, numeric values Validate event coding: Confirm 0/1 appropriate factor levels Review missingness: Address missing time event data Assess outliers: Investigate extremely long short follow-times

title: Person-Time Analysis in jsurvival Module
text: reviewing person-time results: Biological plausibility: rates make clinical sense? Confidence intervals: appropriately wide data? Time trends: time-stratified rates show expected patterns? Group differences: rate differences clinically meaningful?

title: Person-Time Analysis in jsurvival Module
text: Problem: time intervals events Solution: Consider combining intervals using exact Poisson methods

title: Person-Time Analysis in jsurvival Module
text: Problem: Large variation follow-times Solution: Use time-stratified analysis report median follow-

title: Person-Time Analysis in jsurvival Module
text: Problem: Multiple event types affecting person-time Solution: Use competing risks analysis event-specific person-time

title: Person-Time Analysis in jsurvival Module
code: Person-time analysis was performed to calculate incidence rates accounting  for varying follow-up periods. Total person-time was calculated as the sum  of individual follow-up periods from [entry criteria] to [endpoint definition].  Incidence rates were calculated as the number of events divided by person-time  at risk, expressed per [time unit]. Confidence intervals were calculated using  Poisson exact methods. Time-stratified analysis was performed using intervals  of [specify intervals] to assess for time-varying hazards.

title: Person-Time Analysis in jsurvival Module
code: A total of [N] participants contributed [total person-time] [time units] of  follow-up (median [median], range [range]). [Number] events occurred during  the observation period, yielding an overall incidence rate of [rate] per  [multiplier] [time units] (95% CI: [CI]). Incidence rates differed significantly  between [groups]: [group 1] [rate 1] vs. [group 2] [rate 2] per [multiplier]  [time units] (rate ratio [RR], 95% CI: [CI], p=[p-value]).

title: Person-Time Analysis in jsurvival Module
text: Person-time analysis essential proper epidemiological survival analysis. jsurvival module provides comprehensive person-time functionality : Educates users person-time concepts Calculates accurate rates appropriate confidence intervals Enables group comparisons rate ratios differences Supports time-stratified analysis detecting temporal patterns Integrates survival methods comprehensive analysis incorporating person-time analysis survival studies, can: - Provide accurate interpretable results - Enable valid comparisons across studies populations - Better understand temporal patterns data - Meet epidemiological standards rate-based analysis

title: Treatment Response Analysis in Oncology
text: vignette demonstrates treatment response analysis oncology studies using ClinicoPath functions. Treatment response evaluation crucial assessing therapy effectiveness making clinical decisions.

title: Treatment Response Analysis in Oncology
code: # Analyze response categories using basic R if("Response" %in% names(treatmentResponse)) {   cat("Response Categories:\n")   print(table(treatmentResponse$Response, useNA = "ifany")) } else {   cat("Available variables in treatmentResponse:\n")   print(names(treatmentResponse)) } #> Available variables in treatmentResponse: #> [1] "PatientID"     "ResponseValue"

title: Treatment Response Analysis in Oncology
code: # Basic summary statistics continuous_vars <- names(treatmentResponse)[sapply(treatmentResponse, is.numeric)] cat("Continuous variables available:\n") #> Continuous variables available: print(continuous_vars) #> [1] "ResponseValue"  # Example summary if(length(continuous_vars) > 0) {   summary(treatmentResponse[continuous_vars]) } #>  ResponseValue      #>  Min.   :-100.000   #>  1st Qu.: -49.675   #>  Median : -13.300   #>  Mean   :  -6.616   #>  3rd Qu.:  18.900   #>  Max.   : 141.000   #>  NA's   :12

title: Treatment Response Analysis in Oncology
code: # Example of proper crosstable usage for treatment response categorical_vars <- names(treatmentResponse)[sapply(treatmentResponse, function(x) is.factor(x) || is.character(x))]  if(length(categorical_vars) >= 2) {   crosstable(     data = treatmentResponse,     vars = categorical_vars[1:2],     group = categorical_vars[1]   ) } else {   cat("Cross-tabulation analysis available with appropriate categorical variables") } #> Cross-tabulation analysis available with appropriate categorical variables

title: Treatment Response Analysis in Oncology

# RECIST response categories explanation cat("RECIST Response Categories:
") #> RECIST Response Categories: cat("- Complete Response (CR): Disappearance of all target lesions
") #> - Complete Response (CR): Disappearance of all target lesions cat("- Partial Response (PR): ≥30% decrease in sum of target lesions
") #> - Partial Response (PR): ≥30% decrease in sum of target lesions cat("- Progressive Disease (PD): ≥20% increase in sum of target lesions
") #> - Progressive Disease (PD): ≥20% increase in sum of target lesions cat("- Stable Disease (SD): Neither PR nor PD criteria met

") #> - Stable Disease (SD): Neither PR nor PD criteria met  # Check if RECIST categories are present in data recist_cols <- grep("RECIST|Response", names(treatmentResponse), value = TRUE, ignore.case = TRUE) if(length(recist_cols) > 0) {   cat("RECIST-related columns found:", paste(recist_cols, collapse = ", "), "
") } #> RECIST-related columns found: ResponseValue

") } else {   cat("Load appropriate response data for rate calculations

title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Rogers phenomenon statistical paradox occurs medicine patients reclassified disease stages due improvements diagnostic technology changes staging criteria. phenomenon gets name humorous quote attributed American humorist Rogers: “Okies left Oklahoma moved California, raised average intelligence level states.” pathology oncology, phenomenon particularly relevant analyzing impact staging system revisions (TNM edition updates) survival outcomes treatment effectiveness.

what: What is the Will Rogers Phenomenon?
title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Rogers phenomenon describes situation : Stage Migration Occurs: Patients reclassified different disease stages due improved diagnostic methods revised staging criteria. Apparent Improvement: reclassification leads apparent improvements stage-specific outcomes without actual improvement individual patient outcomes. Statistical Paradox: stages appear improved survival rates, overall survival remains unchanged.

previous_headings: Introduction > What is the Will Rogers Phenomenon?
title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Consider lung cancer staging TNM 7th 8th editions: Original System (7th Edition): patient 3.5cm tumor 2 positive lymph nodes classified Stage II New System (8th Edition): patient now classified Stage IIB due refined criteria patient better survival average Stage II patient worse survival average Stage IIB patient: Stage II survival improves (worst patients removed) Stage IIB survival improves (relatively good patients added) patient’s actual prognosis hasn’t changed

previous_headings: Using the Stage Migration Analysis Module > Step 4: Interpret Results
title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Key Metrics: - Total patients: Overall sample size - Unchanged stage: Number patients remaining stage - Stage migration (%): Percentage patients changed stages - Upstaging (%): Percentage moved higher stages - Downstaging (%): Percentage moved lower stages - Chi-square: Statistical test association staging systems Interpretation: - Migration rates >20% indicate substantial staging changes - Significant chi-square suggests non-random migration patterns - Balance upstaging vs. downstaging reveals revision direction

previous_headings: Using the Stage Migration Analysis Module > Step 4: Interpret Results
title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Shows patient distribution changes staging systems: Columns: - Stage: Individual stage categories - Original Count/%): Distribution original system - New Count/(%): Distribution new system - Change: Percentage point change Interpretation: - Large changes indicate major revision impact - Shifts toward early/late stages reveal staging drift - Balanced changes suggest refinement rather systematic bias

previous_headings: Using the Stage Migration Analysis Module > Step 4: Interpret Results
title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Cross-tabulation showing exact patient flow stages: Features: - Rows: Original staging system - Columns: New staging system - Values: Patient counts percentages Interpretation: - Diagonal elements: Patients remaining equivalent stages - -diagonal elements: Migration patterns - High -diagonal values indicate significant reclassification

previous_headings: Using the Stage Migration Analysis Module > Step 4: Interpret Results
title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Compares discriminative ability staging systems: Metrics: - C-index (Harrell’s): Measures discriminative ability (0.5 = random, 1.0 = perfect) - Log-rank test: Tests survival differences within system - AIC: Model quality measure (lower better) Interpretation: - C-index improvement >0.02 clinically meaningful - Lower AIC new system suggests better model fit - Stronger log-rank statistics indicate better stage separation

previous_headings: Using the Stage Migration Analysis Module > Step 4: Interpret Results
title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Identifies evidence phenomenon comparing survival within stages: Columns: - Stage: Original stage analyzed - Unchanged N: Patients remaining stage - Unchanged Median: Median survival unchanged patients - Migrated N: Patients moving different stages - Migrated Median: Median survival migrated patients - p-value: Test comparing unchanged vs. migrated survival Interpretation: - Significant p-values indicate Rogers phenomenon - Different median survivals groups confirm effect - Multiple significant stages suggest systematic migration bias

previous_headings: Using the Stage Migration Analysis Module > Step 5: Visual Interpretation
title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: alluvial/Sankey diagram visualizes patient flow: Elements: - Left axis: Original staging system - Right axis: New staging system - Flow bands: Patient migration pathways - Band thickness: Proportional patient numbers Interpretation: - Thick diagonal flows indicate stage stability - Curved flows show migration patterns - Complex flow patterns suggest major revision impact

previous_headings: Using the Stage Migration Analysis Module > Step 5: Visual Interpretation
title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Kaplan-Meier curves staging system: Features: - Separate plots: Full survival curves system - Side--side: Direct comparison equivalent stages - Confidence intervals: Statistical uncertainty bounds Interpretation: - Better curve separation indicates improved discrimination - Crossing curves suggest staging inconsistencies - Similar overall survival confirms unchanged patient outcomes

previous_headings: Using the Stage Migration Analysis Module > Step 5: Visual Interpretation
title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Bar chart comparing discriminative performance: Elements: - Original System: C-index original staging - New System: C-index new staging - Improvement: Absolute percentage change Interpretation: - Higher bars indicate better discrimination - Positive improvement suggests staging enhancement - Magnitude reflects clinical significance

what: Use Case 1: TNM Staging Revision Impact
title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Scenario: Evaluate impact TNM 8th edition lung cancer staging Analysis Steps: 1. Load dataset TNM 7th 8th edition stages 2. Set “tnm_7th” original stage, “tnm_8th” new stage 3. Use overall survival endpoint 4. Enable Rogers analysis Expected Findings: - Migration rate 25-40% lung cancer - Improved C-index 8th edition (typically +0.02 +0.05) - Evidence Rogers phenomenon Stage II/III patients - Better survival separation new system

title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Scenario: Compare staging different time periods Analysis Steps: 1. Create “era” variable (e.g., 2010-2015 vs. 2016-2020) 2. Compare staging distributions across eras 3. Assess staging drift improvement Expected Findings: - Temporal changes stage distribution - Improved prognostic performance time - Evidence stage migration due better imaging

title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Scenario: Evaluate impact subspecialist review staging Analysis Steps: 1. Compare initial staging vs. subspecialist review 2. Focus difficult cases borderline stages 3. Assess survival impact reclassification Expected Findings: - Systematic upstaging downstaging patterns - Improved prognostic accuracy - Clinical impact subspecialist expertise

title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Minimum: 100 patients adequate follow-Recommended: 200+ patients robust Rogers analysis Power: Consider event rate median follow-time

title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Censoring: Ensure adequate follow-staging systems Competing Risks: Consider disease-specific vs. overall survival Time Bias: Account temporal changes treatment Institution Bias: Consider multi-institutional validation

title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Strong Evidence: - Migration rate >30% - Multiple stages significant Rogers tests - Improved stage-specific survival without overall improvement - C-index improvement primarily redistribution Weak Evidence: - Migration rate <15% - significant Rogers tests - Genuine improvement C-index - Overall survival improvement

title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Clinically Meaningful Changes: - C-index improvement >0.02 - Stage migration affecting >20% patients - Survival differences >6 months systems - Impact treatment decision thresholds

title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Staging Accuracy: Verify staging systems use criteria Missing Data: Assess pattern impact missing stages Follow-Adequacy: Ensure sufficient events follow-Covariate Balance: Check confounding variables

title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: External Validation: Test findings independent cohort Sensitivity Analysis: Test robustness assumptions Clinical Review: Confirm findings make clinical sense Literature Comparison: Compare published staging studies

previous_headings: Reporting Results > Key Elements to Include
title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
code: Stage migration analysis was performed using the ClinicoPath module in jamovi.  Patients were classified according to both [original system] and [new system]  staging criteria. Migration patterns were quantified using cross-tabulation  and chi-square tests. Prognostic performance was compared using Harrell's  C-index and log-rank tests. The Will Rogers phenomenon was assessed by  comparing survival between patients who remained in the same stage versus  those who migrated to different stages.

previous_headings: Reporting Results > Key Elements to Include
title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
code: Of [N] patients analyzed, [X]% experienced stage migration between the  [original] and [new] staging systems (p<0.001). The C-index improved from  [old C-index] to [new C-index] (improvement: +[change], [%] increase).  Evidence of the Will Rogers phenomenon was observed in [N] stages, with  significant survival differences between migrated and non-migrated patients  (p<0.05). Migration predominantly involved [describe pattern].

title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Causation vs. Association: Assuming staging changes cause outcome improvements Clinical vs. Statistical: Overinterpreting small significant changes Generalizability: Extrapolating single-institution findings Complexity: -interpreting complex migration patterns

text: Scenario: Evaluate impact TNM 8th edition lung cancer staging Analysis Steps: 1. Load dataset TNM 7th 8th edition stages 2. Set “tnm_7th” original stage, “tnm_8th” new stage 3. Use overall survival endpoint 4. Enable Rogers analysis Expected Findings: - Migration rate 25-40% lung cancer - Improved C-index 8th edition (typically +0.02 +0.05) - Evidence Rogers phenomenon Stage II/III patients - Better survival separation new system

title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Scenario: Compare staging different time periods Analysis Steps: 1. Create “era” variable (e.g., 2010-2015 vs. 2016-2020) 2. Compare staging distributions across eras 3. Assess staging drift improvement Expected Findings: - Temporal changes stage distribution - Improved prognostic performance time - Evidence stage migration due better imaging

title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Scenario: Evaluate impact subspecialist review staging Analysis Steps: 1. Compare initial staging vs. subspecialist review 2. Focus difficult cases borderline stages 3. Assess survival impact reclassification Expected Findings: - Systematic upstaging downstaging patterns - Improved prognostic accuracy - Clinical impact subspecialist expertise

title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Strong Evidence: - Migration rate >30% - Multiple stages significant Rogers tests - Improved stage-specific survival without overall improvement - C-index improvement primarily redistribution Weak Evidence: - Migration rate <15% - significant Rogers tests - Genuine improvement C-index - Overall survival improvement

title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
code: Stage migration analysis was performed using the ClinicoPath module in jamovi.  Patients were classified according to both [original system] and [new system]  staging criteria. Migration patterns were quantified using cross-tabulation  and chi-square tests. Prognostic performance was compared using Harrell's  C-index and log-rank tests. The Will Rogers phenomenon was assessed by  comparing survival between patients who remained in the same stage versus  those who migrated to different stages.

code: library(ClinicoPath) library(survival) library(dplyr)

title: jsurvival: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Clinical Research
code:
# Load molecular pathology survival data data(ihc_molecular_comprehensive)  # Survival data structure cat("Survival dataset dimensions:", nrow(ihc_molecular_comprehensive), "×", ncol(ihc_molecular_comprehensive), "
")  # Key survival variables survival_vars <- c("Overall_Survival_Months", "Death_Event", "PFS_Months", "Progression_Event") cat("Survival variables:", paste(survival_vars, collapse = ", "), "
")  # Molecular biomarkers for stratification biomarker_vars <- c("EGFR_Mutation", "MSI_Status", "HER2_IHC", "PD_L1_TPS") cat("Biomarker variables:", paste(biomarker_vars, collapse = ", "), "
")  # Basic survival summary survival_summary <- ihc_molecular_comprehensive %>%   summarise(     n = n(),     median_os = median(Overall_Survival_Months),     death_rate = round(mean(Death_Event) * 100, 1),     median_pfs = median(PFS_Months),     progression_rate = round(mean(Progression_Event) * 100, 1)   )  cat("
Survival Summary:
") cat("Patients:", survival_summary$n, "
") cat("Median OS:", survival_summary$median_os, "months
") cat("Death rate:", survival_summary$death_rate, "%
") cat("Median PFS:", survival_summary$median_pfs, "months
") cat("Progression rate:", survival_summary$progression_rate, "%
")

title: jsurvival: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Clinical Research
text: Foundation survival analysis time--event data.
code:
# Kaplan-Meier Analysis Example # In jamovi: jsurvival > Survival Analysis  cat("Kaplan-Meier Survival Analysis
") cat("==============================

")  if(requireNamespace("survival", quietly = TRUE)) {   library(survival)      # Create survival object   surv_obj <- Surv(ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Overall_Survival_Months,                    ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Death_Event)      # Overall survival curve   km_overall <- survfit(surv_obj ~ 1, data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)      cat("Overall Survival Analysis:
")   print(summary(km_overall, times = c(12, 24, 36, 60))$table)      # Survival by EGFR mutation status   km_egfr <- survfit(surv_obj ~ EGFR_Mutation, data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)      cat("
Survival by EGFR Status:
")   egfr_summary <- summary(km_egfr)$table   print(egfr_summary)      # Log-rank test   logrank_egfr <- survdiff(surv_obj ~ EGFR_Mutation, data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)   p_value <- 1 - pchisq(logrank_egfr$chisq, 1)      cat("
Log-rank test p-value:", round(p_value, 4), "
")      if(p_value < 0.05) {     cat("Conclusion: Significant difference in survival by EGFR status
")   } else {     cat("Conclusion: No significant difference in survival by EGFR status
")   } }

title: jsurvival: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Clinical Research
text: Multivariable analysis accounting multiple prognostic factors.
code:
# Cox Regression Analysis Example # In jamovi: jsurvival > Cox Diagnostics  cat("
Cox Proportional Hazards Regression
") cat("===================================

")  if(requireNamespace("survival", quietly = TRUE)) {   # Multivariable Cox model   cox_model <- coxph(Surv(Overall_Survival_Months, Death_Event) ~                       EGFR_Mutation + MSI_Status + Age + Grade + Tumor_Mutational_Burden,                      data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)      cat("Cox Regression Results:
")   cox_summary <- summary(cox_model)   print(cox_summary$coefficients[, c("coef", "exp(coef)", "Pr(>|z|)")])      # Model performance   cat("
Model Performance:
")   cat("Concordance:", round(cox_summary$concordance[1], 3), "
")   cat("R-squared:", round(cox_summary$rsq[1], 3), "
")   cat("Likelihood ratio test p-value:", round(cox_summary$logtest[3], 4), "
")      # Hazard ratios with confidence intervals   cat("
Hazard Ratios (95% CI):
")   hr_ci <- exp(confint(cox_model))   hr_estimates <- exp(cox_model$coefficients)      for(i in 1:length(hr_estimates)) {     var_name <- names(hr_estimates)[i]     hr <- round(hr_estimates[i], 2)     ci_lower <- round(hr_ci[i, 1], 2)     ci_upper <- round(hr_ci[i, 2], 2)     p_val <- round(cox_summary$coefficients[i, "Pr(>|z|)"], 3)          cat(paste0(var_name, ": HR = ", hr, " (", ci_lower, "-", ci_upper, "), p = ", p_val, "
"))   } }

title: jsurvival: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Clinical Research
text: Handle situations multiple types events can occur.
code:
# Competing Risks Analysis Example # In jamovi: jsurvival > Competing Survival  cat("
Competing Risks Analysis
") cat("=======================

")  # Create competing events data # Death from disease vs death from other causes competing_data <- ihc_molecular_comprehensive %>%   mutate(     # Simulate competing events     death_cause = case_when(       Death_Event == 0 ~ "Alive",       Death_Event == 1 & Grade == 3 ~ "Disease",       Death_Event == 1 & Age > 75 ~ "Other",       Death_Event == 1 ~ sample(c("Disease", "Other"), 1, prob = c(0.7, 0.3)),       TRUE ~ "Alive"     ),          # Competing event indicator     event_type = case_when(       death_cause == "Disease" ~ 1,       death_cause == "Other" ~ 2,       TRUE ~ 0     )   )  # Competing risks summary competing_summary <- competing_data %>%   group_by(death_cause) %>%   summarise(     n = n(),     percentage = round(n() / nrow(competing_data) * 100, 1),     median_time = median(Overall_Survival_Months),     .groups = 'drop'   )  cat("Competing Events Summary:
") print(competing_summary)  # Event rates by biomarker status biomarker_events <- competing_data %>%   group_by(EGFR_Mutation, death_cause) %>%   summarise(n = n(), .groups = 'drop') %>%   group_by(EGFR_Mutation) %>%   mutate(percentage = round(n / sum(n) * 100, 1))  cat("
Event Rates by EGFR Status:
") print(biomarker_events)  # Clinical interpretation disease_death_rate <- mean(competing_data$death_cause == "Disease") * 100 cat("
Clinical Interpretation:
") cat("Disease-specific death rate:", round(disease_death_rate, 1), "%
")  if(disease_death_rate > 50) {   cat("Conclusion: Disease is the predominant cause of death
") } else {   cat("Conclusion: Competing causes of death are significant
") }

title: jsurvival: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Clinical Research
text: Evaluate prognostic impact molecular biomarkers.
code:
cat("Molecular Biomarker Survival Analysis
") cat("====================================

")  # Multiple biomarker analysis biomarkers <- c("EGFR_Mutation", "MSI_Status", "HER2_IHC")  for(biomarker in biomarkers) {   cat(paste0("Survival Analysis for ", biomarker, ":
"))   cat(paste0(rep("-", nchar(biomarker) + 25), collapse = ""), "
")      # Create survival object   surv_obj <- Surv(ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Overall_Survival_Months,                    ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Death_Event)      # Survival by biomarker   formula_str <- paste("surv_obj ~", biomarker)   km_biomarker <- survfit(as.formula(formula_str), data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)      # Summary statistics   biomarker_summary <- summary(km_biomarker)$table   print(biomarker_summary)      # Log-rank test   logrank_test <- survdiff(as.formula(formula_str), data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)   p_value <- 1 - pchisq(logrank_test$chisq, length(unique(ihc_molecular_comprehensive[[biomarker]])) - 1)      cat("Log-rank test p-value:", round(p_value, 4), "
")      if(p_value < 0.05) {     cat("Result: Significant prognostic biomarker
")   } else {     cat("Result: Not a significant prognostic biomarker
")   }   cat("
") }

title: jsurvival: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Clinical Research
text: Evaluate continuous biomarkers like PD-L1 expression tumor mutational burden.
code:
cat("Continuous Biomarker Analysis
") cat("=============================

")  # PD-L1 TPS analysis pdl1_quartiles <- quantile(ihc_molecular_comprehensive$PD_L1_TPS,                            probs = c(0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1.0))  ihc_with_quartiles <- ihc_molecular_comprehensive %>%   mutate(     PD_L1_Quartile = cut(PD_L1_TPS,                          breaks = pdl1_quartiles,                         labels = c("Q1 (Low)", "Q2", "Q3", "Q4 (High)"),                         include.lowest = TRUE),          PD_L1_Clinical = case_when(       PD_L1_TPS < 1 ~ "Negative (<1%)",       PD_L1_TPS < 50 ~ "Low Positive (1-49%)",       TRUE ~ "High Positive (≥50%)"     )   )  cat("PD-L1 TPS Distribution:
") pdl1_dist <- table(ihc_with_quartiles$PD_L1_Clinical) print(pdl1_dist)  # Survival by PD-L1 clinical categories if(requireNamespace("survival", quietly = TRUE)) {   surv_obj <- Surv(ihc_with_quartiles$Overall_Survival_Months,                    ihc_with_quartiles$Death_Event)      km_pdl1 <- survfit(surv_obj ~ PD_L1_Clinical, data = ihc_with_quartiles)      cat("
Survival by PD-L1 Expression Level:
")   pdl1_summary <- summary(km_pdl1)$table   print(pdl1_summary)      # Test for trend   logrank_pdl1 <- survdiff(surv_obj ~ PD_L1_Clinical, data = ihc_with_quartiles)   p_value_pdl1 <- 1 - pchisq(logrank_pdl1$chisq, 2)      cat("Log-rank test p-value:", round(p_value_pdl1, 4), "
")      # Tumor mutational burden analysis   tmb_median <- median(ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Tumor_Mutational_Burden)   tmb_high <- ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Tumor_Mutational_Burden >= tmb_median      cat("
Tumor Mutational Burden Analysis:
")   cat("Median TMB:", tmb_median, "mutations/Mb
")   cat("TMB-High cases:", sum(tmb_high), "(", round(mean(tmb_high) * 100, 1), "%)
")      # TMB survival analysis   km_tmb <- survfit(surv_obj ~ tmb_high, data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)   tmb_summary <- summary(km_tmb)$table      cat("Survival by TMB Status:
")   print(tmb_summary) }

title: jsurvival: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Clinical Research
text: Develop comprehensive prognostic models incorporating multiple biomarkers.
code:
cat("Multivariable Prognostic Model Development
") cat("=========================================

")  if(requireNamespace("survival", quietly = TRUE)) {   # Comprehensive prognostic model   prog_model <- coxph(Surv(Overall_Survival_Months, Death_Event) ~                        Age + Grade +                        EGFR_Mutation + MSI_Status +                        PD_L1_TPS + Tumor_Mutational_Burden,                       data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)      # Model summary   prog_summary <- summary(prog_model)      cat("Comprehensive Prognostic Model:
")   print(prog_summary$coefficients[, c("coef", "exp(coef)", "Pr(>|z|)")])      # Model performance metrics   cat("
Model Performance:
")   cat("Concordance index:", round(prog_summary$concordance[1], 3), "
")   cat("Standard error:", round(prog_summary$concordance[2], 3), "
")      # Risk score calculation   risk_scores <- predict(prog_model, type = "risk")   risk_tertiles <- cut(risk_scores,                        breaks = quantile(risk_scores, probs = c(0, 1/3, 2/3, 1)),                       labels = c("Low Risk", "Intermediate Risk", "High Risk"),                       include.lowest = TRUE)      # Risk group validation   risk_validation <- ihc_molecular_comprehensive %>%     mutate(Risk_Group = risk_tertiles) %>%     group_by(Risk_Group) %>%     summarise(       n = n(),       events = sum(Death_Event),       event_rate = round(mean(Death_Event) * 100, 1),       median_survival = median(Overall_Survival_Months),       .groups = 'drop'     )      cat("
Risk Group Validation:
")   print(risk_validation)      # Test risk stratification   surv_risk <- Surv(ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Overall_Survival_Months,                     ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Death_Event)      km_risk <- survfit(surv_risk ~ risk_tertiles)   logrank_risk <- survdiff(surv_risk ~ risk_tertiles)   p_value_risk <- 1 - pchisq(logrank_risk$chisq, 2)      cat("Risk stratification p-value:", round(p_value_risk, 4), "
")      if(p_value_risk < 0.001) {     cat("Conclusion: Excellent risk stratification achieved
")   } else if(p_value_risk < 0.05) {     cat("Conclusion: Significant risk stratification achieved
")   } else {     cat("Conclusion: Risk stratification needs improvement
")   } }

title: Person-Time Analysis in jsurvival Module
code: Person-time analysis was performed to calculate incidence rates accounting  for varying follow-up periods. Total person-time was calculated as the sum  of individual follow-up periods from [entry criteria] to [endpoint definition].  Incidence rates were calculated as the number of events divided by person-time  at risk, expressed per [time unit]. Confidence intervals were calculated using  Poisson exact methods. Time-stratified analysis was performed using intervals  of [specify intervals] to assess for time-varying hazards.

title: Treatment Response Analysis in Oncology
text: Treatment response analysis crucial oncology research evaluating therapeutic efficacy understanding patient outcomes. vignette demonstrates specialized functions ClinicoPathDescriptives analyzing treatment response data, including waterfall plots, swimmer plots, RECIST criteria implementation.

title: Treatment Response Analysis in Oncology
text: Response Evaluation Criteria Solid Tumors (RECIST) provides standardized guidelines measuring treatment response: Complete Response (CR): Disappearance target lesions Partial Response (PR): ≥30% decrease sum target lesion diameters Progressive Disease (PD): ≥20% increase sum target lesion diameters Stable Disease (SD): Neither PR PD criteria met
code: library(ClinicoPath) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) library(knitr)  # Load both datasets data(treatmentResponse) data(histopathology)  # Examine treatment response data structure head(treatmentResponse) #>   PatientID ResponseValue #> 1    PT0001          63.5 #> 2    PT0002        -100.0 #> 3    PT0003         -20.5 #> 4    PT0004          55.1 #> 5    PT0005         -60.5 #> 6    PT0006         -93.6 summary(treatmentResponse$ResponseValue) #>     Min.  1st Qu.   Median     Mean  3rd Qu.     Max.     NA's  #> -100.000  -49.675  -13.300   -6.616   18.900  141.000       12

title: Treatment Response Analysis in Oncology
code:
# Create comprehensive treatment response dataset response_data <- treatmentResponse %>%   mutate(     # RECIST classification based on percentage change     RECIST_Response = case_when(       is.na(ResponseValue) ~ "Not Evaluable",       ResponseValue <= -30 ~ "Partial Response (PR)",       ResponseValue > -30 & ResponseValue < 20 ~ "Stable Disease (SD)",       ResponseValue >= 20 ~ "Progressive Disease (PD)"     ),     # Additional response categories     Response_Category = case_when(       is.na(ResponseValue) ~ "Missing",       ResponseValue < 0 ~ "Tumor Shrinkage",       ResponseValue == 0 ~ "No Change",       ResponseValue > 0 ~ "Tumor Growth"     ),     # Best response categories     Best_Response = case_when(       ResponseValue <= -50 ~ "Major Response",       ResponseValue <= -30 ~ "Partial Response",       ResponseValue > -30 & ResponseValue < 20 ~ "Stable Disease",       ResponseValue >= 20 & ResponseValue < 50 ~ "Progressive Disease",       ResponseValue >= 50 ~ "Rapid Progression",       TRUE ~ "Not Evaluable"     ),     # Extract patient number for sorting     PatientNum = as.numeric(gsub("PT", "", PatientID))   ) %>%   arrange(ResponseValue)  # Summary statistics cat("Treatment Response Dataset Summary:
") #> Treatment Response Dataset Summary: cat("Total Patients:", nrow(response_data), "
") #> Total Patients: 250 cat("Evaluable Patients:", sum(!is.na(response_data$ResponseValue)), "
") #> Evaluable Patients: 238 cat("Missing Data:", sum(is.na(response_data$ResponseValue)), "

") #> Missing Data: 12  # Response distribution table(response_data$RECIST_Response) #>  #>            Not Evaluable    Partial Response (PR) Progressive Disease (PD)  #>                       12                       77                       58  #>      Stable Disease (SD)  #>                      103

text: Swimmer plots show individual patient timelines, treatment durations, clinical events time.
code: # Prepare data for swimmer plot by merging with clinical data # Create synthetic timeline data based on available information swimmer_data <- histopathology %>%   select(ID, Group, OverallTime, Outcome, Death, TStage, Grade) %>%   mutate(     PatientID = paste0("PT", sprintf("%04d", ID)),     Treatment_Duration = pmax(1, OverallTime * runif(n(), 0.6, 1.0)), # Synthetic treatment duration     Event_Time = ifelse(Outcome == 1, OverallTime, NA),     Response_Time = Treatment_Duration * runif(n(), 0.3, 0.8), # Synthetic response assessment time     Treatment_Status = case_when(       Death == "DOĞRU" ~ "Discontinued - Death",       Outcome == 1 ~ "Discontinued - Progression",        TRUE ~ "Ongoing"     )   ) %>%   filter(ID <= 50) %>%  # Limit to first 50 patients for clarity   arrange(desc(OverallTime))  # Generate swimmer plot swimmerplot(   data = swimmer_data,   patientID = "PatientID",   start = "Treatment_Duration",   end = "OverallTime",   event = NULL,   sortVariable = NULL,   milestone1Date = NULL,   milestone2Date = NULL,   milestone3Date = NULL,   milestone4Date = NULL,   milestone5Date = NULL ) #>  #>  PATIENT TIMELINE ANALYSIS #>  #> character(0) #>  #>  Timeline Summary                         #>  ───────────────────────────────────────  #>    Metric                 Value           #>  ───────────────────────────────────────  #>    Median Duration         0.047242801    #>    Mean Duration           0.050070678    #>    Standard Deviation      0.030050080    #>    Range                   0.116550417    #>    Minimum                 0.001049594    #>    Maximum                 0.117600011    #>    25th Percentile         0.026115645    #>    75th Percentile         0.071960084    #>    Total Person-Time       2.453463230    #>    Number of Subjects     50.000000000    #>    Mean Follow-up Time     0.050070678    #>  ─────────────────────────────────────── #> TableGrob (2 x 1) "arrange": 2 grobs #>   z     cells    name           grob #> 1 1 (1-1,1-1) arrange gtable[layout] #> 2 2 (2-2,1-1) arrange gtable[layout]

title: Treatment Response Analysis in Oncology
text: Treatment Response Rates Study Group
code: # Calculate response rates by subgroup response_rates <- combined_data %>%   filter(!is.na(RECIST_Response) & RECIST_Response != "Not Evaluable") %>%   group_by(Group) %>%   summarise(     Total_Patients = n(),     PR_Count = sum(RECIST_Response == "Partial Response (PR)"),     SD_Count = sum(RECIST_Response == "Stable Disease (SD)"),     PD_Count = sum(RECIST_Response == "Progressive Disease (PD)"),     Overall_Response_Rate = round(PR_Count / Total_Patients * 100, 1),     Disease_Control_Rate = round((PR_Count + SD_Count) / Total_Patients * 100, 1),     Progressive_Disease_Rate = round(PD_Count / Total_Patients * 100, 1),     .groups = 'drop'   )  kable(response_rates,       caption = "Treatment Response Rates by Study Group",       col.names = c("Group", "Total", "PR", "SD", "PD",                      "ORR (%)", "DCR (%)", "PDR (%)"))

title: Treatment Response Analysis in Oncology
text: Best Response Distribution Treatment Group
code: # Analyze best response categories best_response_summary <- combined_data %>%   filter(!is.na(Best_Response)) %>%   group_by(Group, Best_Response) %>%   summarise(Count = n(), .groups = 'drop') %>%   group_by(Group) %>%   mutate(Percentage = round(Count / sum(Count) * 100, 1)) %>%   arrange(Group, desc(Count))  kable(best_response_summary,       caption = "Best Response Distribution by Treatment Group")

text: meddecide includes comprehensive datasets decision analysis training:
code:
# Load decision analysis datasets data(basic_decision_data) data(markov_decision_data)  data(precision_oncology_data)  # Decision tree data overview cat("Basic decision data dimensions:", nrow(basic_decision_data), "×", ncol(basic_decision_data), "
") cat("Key variables:", paste(names(basic_decision_data)[1:8], collapse = ", "), "...
")  # Markov model data overview cat("Markov decision data dimensions:", nrow(markov_decision_data), "×", ncol(markov_decision_data), "
") cat("Key variables:", paste(names(markov_decision_data)[1:8], collapse = ", "), "...
")  # Precision oncology data overview cat("Precision oncology data dimensions:", nrow(precision_oncology_data), "×", ncol(precision_oncology_data), "
") molecular_vars <- names(precision_oncology_data)[grepl("Mutation|Status|TPS", names(precision_oncology_data))] cat("Biomarker variables:", paste(molecular_vars[1:5], collapse = ", "), "...
")

what: 1. ROC Analysis and Diagnostic Test Evaluation
title: MedDecide 01: Introduction to Medical Decision Analysis for Pathologists
text: Foundation biomarker validation diagnostic test assessment.
code:
# ROC Analysis Example # In jamovi: meddecide > ROC > ROC Analysis  # Using precision oncology data for biomarker evaluation data(precision_oncology_data)  # Create binary outcome for treatment response response_binary <- as.numeric(precision_oncology_data$Treatment_Response %in%                               c("Complete_Response", "Partial_Response"))  cat("ROC Analysis Example - PD-L1 TPS for Treatment Response
") cat("=====================================================

")  # Basic ROC statistics if(requireNamespace("pROC", quietly = TRUE)) {   library(pROC)      # ROC analysis for PD-L1 TPS   roc_pdl1 <- roc(response_binary, precision_oncology_data$PD_L1_TPS, quiet = TRUE)      cat("PD-L1 TPS ROC Results:
")   cat("AUC:", round(auc(roc_pdl1), 3), "
")   cat("95% CI:", paste(round(ci.auc(roc_pdl1), 3), collapse = " - "), "
")      # Optimal cutpoint   optimal_cutpoint <- coords(roc_pdl1, "best", ret = "threshold")   cat("Optimal cutpoint:", round(optimal_cutpoint, 1), "%
")      # Clinical cutpoints evaluation   cutpoints <- c(1, 10, 20, 50)   cat("
Performance at Clinical Cutpoints:
")      for(cutpoint in cutpoints) {     sens <- coords(roc_pdl1, cutpoint, ret = "sensitivity")     spec <- coords(roc_pdl1, cutpoint, ret = "specificity")     cat(paste0("PD-L1 ≥", cutpoint, "%: Sensitivity = ", round(sens, 3),                ", Specificity = ", round(spec, 3), "
"))   } }  # Diagnostic test characteristics n_positive <- sum(precision_oncology_data$PD_L1_TPS >= 50) n_total <- nrow(precision_oncology_data) prevalence <- round(n_positive / n_total * 100, 1)  cat("
Diagnostic Test Characteristics:
") cat("PD-L1 ≥50% prevalence:", prevalence, "%
") cat("Sample size:", n_total, "patients
")

title: MedDecide 01: Introduction to Medical Decision Analysis for Pathologists
text: Evaluate treatment alternatives immediate outcomes.
code:
# Decision Tree Analysis Example # In jamovi: meddecide > Decision > Decision Tree Graph  # Using basic decision data data(basic_decision_data)  cat("Decision Tree Analysis Example - Surgery vs Medical Treatment
") cat("===========================================================

")  # Decision analysis summary decision_summary <- basic_decision_data %>%   group_by(treatment) %>%   summarise(     n = n(),     mean_prob_success = round(mean(prob_success_surgery + prob_success_medical)/2, 3),     mean_cost = round(mean(cost_surgery + cost_medical)/2, 0),     mean_utility_success = round(mean(utility_success), 3),     clinical_response_rate = round(mean(clinical_outcome == "Complete_Response") * 100, 1),     .groups = 'drop'   )  cat("Decision Alternatives:
") print(decision_summary)  # Expected value calculation example surgery_cases <- basic_decision_data[basic_decision_data$treatment == "Surgery", ] medical_cases <- basic_decision_data[basic_decision_data$treatment == "Medical Treatment", ]  if(nrow(surgery_cases) > 0 && nrow(medical_cases) > 0) {   # Surgery expected values   surgery_ev_cost <- mean(surgery_cases$cost_surgery * surgery_cases$prob_success_surgery +                           surgery_cases$cost_complications * surgery_cases$prob_complications)      surgery_ev_utility <- mean(surgery_cases$utility_success * surgery_cases$prob_success_surgery +                              surgery_cases$utility_failure * (1 - surgery_cases$prob_success_surgery))      # Medical treatment expected values     medical_ev_cost <- mean(medical_cases$cost_medical * medical_cases$prob_success_medical)      medical_ev_utility <- mean(medical_cases$utility_success * medical_cases$prob_success_medical +                              medical_cases$utility_failure * (1 - medical_cases$prob_success_medical))      cat("
Expected Value Analysis:
")   cat("Surgery - Expected Cost: $", round(surgery_ev_cost, 0),        ", Expected Utility: ", round(surgery_ev_utility, 3), "
")   cat("Medical - Expected Cost: $", round(medical_ev_cost, 0),        ", Expected Utility: ", round(medical_ev_utility, 3), "
")      # Cost-effectiveness ratio   if(medical_ev_utility != surgery_ev_utility) {     icer <- (surgery_ev_cost - medical_ev_cost) / (surgery_ev_utility - medical_ev_utility)     cat("Incremental Cost-Effectiveness Ratio: $", round(abs(icer), 0), " per utility unit
")   } }

title: MedDecide 01: Introduction to Medical Decision Analysis for Pathologists
text: Long-term disease progression modeling chronic conditions.
code:
# Markov Model Analysis Example # In jamovi: meddecide > Decision > Decision Tree Graph (Markov Model Tree)  # Using markov decision data data(markov_decision_data)  cat("Markov Model Analysis Example - Chronic Disease Management
") cat("=========================================================

")  # Treatment strategy comparison strategy_summary <- markov_decision_data %>%   group_by(treatment_strategy) %>%   summarise(     n_states = n(),     mean_healthy_to_sick = round(mean(prob_healthy_to_sick), 4),     mean_sick_to_recovered = round(mean(prob_sick_to_recovered), 4),     annual_cost_healthy = round(mean(cost_healthy_state), 0),     annual_cost_sick = round(mean(cost_sick_state), 0),     annual_utility_healthy = round(mean(utility_healthy), 3),     annual_utility_sick = round(mean(utility_sick), 3),     .groups = 'drop'   )  cat("Treatment Strategy Comparison:
") print(strategy_summary)  # Transition probability validation cat("
Transition Probability Validation:
") sample_state <- markov_decision_data[1, ] prob_sum <- sample_state$prob_healthy_to_sick + (1 - sample_state$prob_healthy_to_sick) cat("Probability sum check (should = 1.0):", prob_sum, "
")  # Long-term outcome simulation (simplified) time_horizon <- 10  # years initial_cohort <- 1000  cat("
Simulated 10-Year Outcomes (per 1000 patients):
") for(strategy in unique(markov_decision_data$treatment_strategy)) {   strategy_data <- markov_decision_data[markov_decision_data$treatment_strategy == strategy, ][1, ]      # Simplified simulation   annual_transition_rate <- strategy_data$prob_healthy_to_sick   annual_recovery_rate <- strategy_data$prob_sick_to_recovered      # Estimate patients progressing over time horizon   patients_progressing <- round(initial_cohort * annual_transition_rate * time_horizon)      # Estimate total costs   total_cost <- strategy_data$cost_healthy_state * time_horizon +                  patients_progressing * strategy_data$cost_sick_state      cat(paste0(strategy, ": ", patients_progressing, " progressions, $",              round(total_cost, 0), " total cost
")) }

title: MedDecide 01: Introduction to Medical Decision Analysis for Pathologists
text: Biomarker-guided treatment selection cost-effectiveness evaluation.
code:
# Precision Medicine Decision Analysis # Combining diagnostic testing with treatment selection  data(precision_oncology_data)  cat("Precision Medicine Decision Analysis
") cat("===================================

")  # Biomarker testing strategy evaluation biomarker_strategy <- precision_oncology_data %>%   mutate(     # Define testing strategy     test_egfr = TRUE,  # Universal EGFR testing     test_pdl1 = TRUE,  # Universal PD-L1 testing          # Treatment assignment based on biomarkers     recommended_treatment = case_when(       EGFR_Mutation == "Positive" ~ "EGFR_TKI",       PD_L1_TPS >= 50 ~ "Anti_PD1_Mono",       PD_L1_TPS >= 1 ~ "Combo_Immuno",       TRUE ~ "Chemotherapy"     ),          # Estimate treatment costs     treatment_cost = case_when(       recommended_treatment == "EGFR_TKI" ~ 120000,       recommended_treatment == "Anti_PD1_Mono" ~ 150000,       recommended_treatment == "Combo_Immuno" ~ 200000,       TRUE ~ 80000     ),          # Testing costs     testing_cost = 3000,  # Comprehensive biomarker panel          # Total cost     total_cost = treatment_cost + testing_cost   )  # Strategy outcomes strategy_outcomes <- biomarker_strategy %>%   group_by(recommended_treatment) %>%   summarise(     n_patients = n(),     percentage = round(n() / nrow(biomarker_strategy) * 100, 1),     response_rate = round(mean(Treatment_Response %in% c("Complete_Response", "Partial_Response")) * 100, 1),     median_pfs = median(PFS_Months),     mean_cost = round(mean(total_cost), 0),     .groups = 'drop'   )  cat("Biomarker-Guided Treatment Strategy Outcomes:
") print(strategy_outcomes)  # Cost-effectiveness summary total_responses <- sum(biomarker_strategy$Treatment_Response %in% c("Complete_Response", "Partial_Response")) total_cost <- sum(biomarker_strategy$total_cost) cost_per_response <- round(total_cost / total_responses, 0)  cat("
Overall Strategy Performance:
") cat("Total patients:", nrow(biomarker_strategy), "
") cat("Total responses:", total_responses, "
") cat("Response rate:", round(total_responses / nrow(biomarker_strategy) * 100, 1), "%
") cat("Cost per response: $", cost_per_response, "
")  # Compare with standard care (no biomarker testing) standard_care_response_rate <- 25  # Assumed standard chemotherapy response rate standard_care_cost <- 80000  # Standard chemotherapy cost cost_per_response_standard <- round(standard_care_cost / (standard_care_response_rate/100), 0)  cat("
Comparison with Standard Care:
") cat("Standard care cost per response: $", cost_per_response_standard, "
") cat("Biomarker strategy cost per response: $", cost_per_response, "
")  if(cost_per_response < cost_per_response_standard) {   cat("Biomarker strategy is more cost-effective
") } else {   cat("Standard care is more cost-effective
") }

title: MedDecide 01: Introduction to Medical Decision Analysis for Pathologists
text: Evaluate diagnostic test reliability inter-observer agreement.
code:
cat("Agreement Analysis Applications
") cat("==============================

")  # Load biomarker validation data for agreement analysis data(biomarker_validation_study)  # Multi-platform agreement platform_agreement <- biomarker_validation_study %>%   summarise(     n_cases = n(),     correlation = round(cor(Platform_A_PD_L1, Platform_B_PD_L1), 3),     mean_difference = round(mean(Platform_B_PD_L1 - Platform_A_PD_L1), 2),     agreement_within_10pct = round(mean(abs(Platform_B_PD_L1 - Platform_A_PD_L1) <= 10) * 100, 1),     overall_agreement = round(mean(Platform_Agreement) * 100, 1)   )  cat("Multi-Platform Biomarker Agreement:
") cat("Cases analyzed:", platform_agreement$n_cases, "
") cat("Correlation:", platform_agreement$correlation, "
") cat("Mean difference:", platform_agreement$mean_difference, "%
") cat("Agreement within ±10%:", platform_agreement$agreement_within_10pct, "%
") cat("Overall agreement:", platform_agreement$overall_agreement, "%
")  # Clinical significance if(platform_agreement$correlation >= 0.90 && platform_agreement$overall_agreement >= 85) {   cat("Conclusion: Platforms show excellent agreement for clinical use
") } else {   cat("Conclusion: Platform harmonization may be needed
") }

title: MedDecide 01: Introduction to Medical Decision Analysis for Pathologists
text: Sample size statistical power calculations diagnostic studies.
code:
cat("
Power Analysis for Diagnostic Studies
") cat("====================================

")  # Sample size calculation for ROC analysis # Based on AUC difference detection  auc_null <- 0.5      # Null hypothesis (no discrimination) auc_alternative <- 0.75  # Alternative hypothesis (good discrimination) alpha <- 0.05        # Type I error rate power <- 0.80        # Desired power  # Simplified sample size estimation # Using normal approximation for AUC z_alpha <- qnorm(1 - alpha/2)  # 1.96 for 95% confidence z_beta <- qnorm(power)         # 0.84 for 80% power  # Approximate sample size (simplified formula) estimated_n <- ((z_alpha + z_beta)^2 * 2) / ((auc_alternative - auc_null)^2 * 4)  cat("Sample Size Estimation for ROC Study:
") cat("Null AUC:", auc_null, "
") cat("Alternative AUC:", auc_alternative, "
")  cat("Alpha:", alpha, "
") cat("Power:", power, "
") cat("Estimated sample size:", round(estimated_n), "per group
") cat("Total sample size:", round(estimated_n * 2), "
")  # Recommendations if(estimated_n < 50) {   cat("Recommendation: Small study feasible
") } else if(estimated_n < 200) {   cat("Recommendation: Moderate-sized study required
") } else {   cat("Recommendation: Large study required, consider multi-center collaboration
") }

title: meddecide: Medical Decision Making in R
text: meddecide package provides comprehensive tools medical decision-making, including: ROC Analysis: Receiver Operating Characteristic curve analysis optimal cutpoint determination Diagnostic Test Evaluation: Sensitivity, specificity, predictive values, likelihood ratios Interrater Reliability: Cohen’s kappa Fleiss’ kappa agreement analysis Power Analysis: Sample size calculations kappa statistics

title: meddecide: Medical Decision Making in R
text: ROC (Receiver Operating Characteristic) analysis fundamental evaluating diagnostic tests. psychopdaroc function provides comprehensive ROC analysis multiple methods determining optimal cutpoints.

title: meddecide: Medical Decision Making in R
code: library(ClinicoPath)  # Load example data data(cancer_biomarker)  # Hypothetical dataset  # Basic ROC analysis roc_result <- psychopdaroc(   data = cancer_biomarker,   dependentVars = "PSA",           # Test variable   classVar = "cancer_status",      # Binary outcome (0/1)   positiveClass = "1"              # Which level is positive )

title: meddecide: Medical Decision Making in R
text: ROC curve plots sensitivity (true positive rate) 1-specificity (false positive rate) across possible cutpoints. area curve (AUC) summarizes overall diagnostic accuracy: AUC = 0.5: discrimination (diagonal line) AUC = 0.7-0.8: Acceptable discrimination AUC = 0.8-0.9: Excellent discrimination AUC > 0.9: Outstanding discrimination

title: meddecide: Medical Decision Making in R
text: package offers several methods determine optimal cutpoints:
code: # Method 1: Maximize Youden's Index (default) roc_youden <- psychopdaroc(   data = cancer_biomarker,   dependentVars = "PSA",   classVar = "cancer_status",   positiveClass = "1",   method = "maximize_metric",   metric = "youden"  # Sensitivity + Specificity - 1 )  # Method 2: Cost-benefit optimization roc_cost <- psychopdaroc(   data = cancer_biomarker,   dependentVars = "PSA",   classVar = "cancer_status",   positiveClass = "1",   method = "oc_cost_ratio",   costratioFP = 2.5  # False positives cost 2.5x more than false negatives )  # Method 3: Equal sensitivity and specificity roc_equal <- psychopdaroc(   data = cancer_biomarker,   dependentVars = "PSA",   classVar = "cancer_status",   positiveClass = "1",   method = "oc_equal_sens_spec" )

title: meddecide: Medical Decision Making in R
code: # Compare multiple biomarkers roc_comparison <- psychopdaroc(   data = cancer_biomarker,   dependentVars = c("PSA", "CA125", "CEA"),  # Multiple tests   classVar = "cancer_status",   positiveClass = "1",   combinePlots = TRUE,        # Show all curves in one plot   delongTest = TRUE           # Statistical comparison of AUCs )

title: meddecide: Medical Decision Making in R
code: # Bootstrap confidence intervals roc_bootstrap <- psychopdaroc(   data = cancer_biomarker,   dependentVars = "PSA",   classVar = "cancer_status",   positiveClass = "1",   bootstrapCI = TRUE,   bootstrapReps = 2000 )  # Partial AUC (focus on high specificity region) roc_partial <- psychopdaroc(   data = cancer_biomarker,   dependentVars = "PSA",   classVar = "cancer_status",   positiveClass = "1",   partialAUC = TRUE,   partialAUCfrom = 0.8,  # Specificity range 80-100%   partialAUCto = 1.0 )  # Net Reclassification Index (NRI) and IDI roc_nri <- psychopdaroc(   data = cancer_biomarker,   dependentVars = c("PSA", "NewBiomarker"),   classVar = "cancer_status",   positiveClass = "1",   calculateIDI = TRUE,   calculateNRI = TRUE,   refVar = "PSA",  # Compare NewBiomarker against PSA   nriThresholds = "0.2,0.5"  # Risk categories: <20%, 20-50%, >50% )

title: meddecide: Medical Decision Making in R
code: # Publication-ready plots roc_publication <- psychopdaroc(   data = cancer_biomarker,   dependentVars = c("PSA", "CA125"),   classVar = "cancer_status",   positiveClass = "1",   plotROC = TRUE,   cleanPlot = TRUE,           # Clean plot for publications   showOptimalPoint = TRUE,    # Mark optimal cutpoint   legendPosition = "bottomright" )  # Additional diagnostic plots roc_diagnostic <- psychopdaroc(   data = cancer_biomarker,   dependentVars = "PSA",   classVar = "cancer_status",   positiveClass = "1",   showCriterionPlot = TRUE,   # Sensitivity/Specificity vs threshold   showPrevalencePlot = TRUE,  # PPV/NPV vs prevalence   showDotPlot = TRUE          # Distribution by class )

title: meddecide: Medical Decision Making in R
text: agreement function assesses well multiple raters agree classifying subjects.

title: meddecide: Medical Decision Making in R
code: # Two pathologists rating tumor grades kappa_result <- agreement(   data = pathology_data,   vars = c("pathologist1", "pathologist2") )

title: meddecide: Medical Decision Making in R
text: κ < 0.00: Poor agreement κ = 0.00-0.20: Slight agreement κ = 0.21-0.40: Fair agreement κ = 0.41-0.60: Moderate agreement κ = 0.61-0.80: Substantial agreement κ = 0.81-1.00: Almost perfect agreement

title: meddecide: Medical Decision Making in R
code: # For ordinal categories (e.g., grades 1-5) weighted_kappa <- agreement(   data = pathology_data,   vars = c("pathologist1", "pathologist2"),   wght = "squared"  # Squared weights for ordinal data )

title: meddecide: Medical Decision Making in R
code: # Three or more raters fleiss_kappa <- agreement(   data = radiology_data,   vars = c("radiologist1", "radiologist2", "radiologist3", "radiologist4") )

title: meddecide: Medical Decision Making in R
code: # For small samples with 3+ raters exact_kappa <- agreement(   data = small_study,   vars = c("rater1", "rater2", "rater3"),   exct = TRUE  # Use exact method )
